bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, July 1, 1938

div1.p: Andrus requests Moran's assistance in getting a bill passed to honor Ames and Lambert.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to John J. Moran, July 1, 1938
div1.opener:
7-1-38
FROM GUST LAMBERT
Mr. John J. Moran,
Avenida Menocal 102-A,
Havana Cuba.
Dear Friend Moran:
div1.p:
Heard a brief radio preview of Yellow Jack and found that the
authors had subordinated historical facts in favor of a cloy-
ing - and entirely imiginary - “love interest.”

My Mother, Son and Daughter-in-law saw the picture and their
reaction was that the “drahma” seemed forced.

Do you remember Dr. Ames' man Friday - Gust. Lambert?
He was the Corps man assigned, with Dr. Ames, to the yellow
fever hospital at Columbia Barracks.

If Lambert meant anywhere near as much to you, when you were
sick with yellow fever, as he did to me when I was sick, you
will not have forgotten him. Of course I remember that
there were two female, immune, practical nurses at the hos-
pital but I also remember that Lambert was the REAL nurse and
was so recognized by Dr. Ames.

You and I know that the success of Major Reed's experiments
was due, in large measure, to his ability to get a sufficient
number of volunteers to conclusively prove his theories.

We likewise know that, had there been two or three deaths
among the volunteers, there would have been no more willing
to risk their lives and Major Reed's work would have been
halted.

For this reason I have fealt that there was grave injustice
in not recognizing the work of Dr. Ames and Lambert.

For the last several years there have been bills in Congress
to honor Dr. Ames and Lambert for their work. Each time
the bills have passed the Seante but have been held up in the
House.

Dr. Ames is dead but his widow is living. Lambert is liv-
ing in Chicago. If you feel as I do about this will you
make affidavit that, during your illness with experimental
yellow fever, you were under the care of Dr. Roger Post Ames
and that your nurse, under Dr. Ames' direction was Gust. E.
Lambert?
FROM GUST LAMBERT

A few days ago a gentleman called me on the 'phone from Phil-
adelphia, told me the Philadelphia Council od Spanish War
Veterans were to present a placque to Walter Reed Hospital,
in honor of Major Reed and asking if they could come and see me.

In response to my “yes” they appeared. Four veterans, two
reporters from the Evening Ledger and a camerman.

The garbled result is the enclosure. (Parts marked out
did not come from me.)

I have never sought publicity and never become involved (as in
this instance) that I do not regret it.
Bye the way - I refused to let the photographer do his stuff.

A friend sent me a newspaper clipping:
“John R. Kissinger, an outstanding Spanish War
Veteran, who won renown by submitting himself
as a human guinea pig for yellow fever exper-
iments would be appointed a major on the retired
list of the Army if Congress had acted favorably
on a bill introduced by Representative Glenn
Griswold, of Indiana. Kissinger . . spent
several days in Washington recently as the guest
of Senator Frederick Van Muye and was feted by
the management of Loew's Theaters in connection
with the showing of Yellow Jack a . . Two other
known survivors of the yellow fever experiments
are are John J. Moran, now associated with the
Sun Oil Co., in Havana and Dr. Robert Cook of
Lexington, Va.”

I hope that the fates are treating you kindly and that, some
day in the not too distant future, you may be able to stop in
and see me.
With kindest regards and best wishes.
